newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish shares extend gains, seen losing steam.
newsitem.headline: Polish shares extend gains, seen losing steam.

text.p: Polish shares rose for the third day running but analysts saw the market losing steam on Thursday as the current technical rebound ends.

The bourse, now at 15,510 points, had fallen about 1,000 points during the last three weeks of July on macroeconomic concerns deepened by flooding, which led to Monday's two-point rise of the lombard rate and 2.5-point rise of the discount.

"It was possible to expect that the NBP would raise rates but whether the scale was expected is another question...and I don't think it has already been completely priced in," said Andrzej Soldek, an analyst at ING BSK Asset Management.

The main market's all-share WIG index rose 1.6 percent to 15,510.0 points and turnover rose 22.2 percent to 183.1 million zlotys ($52.2 million) on both markets. Gainers led losers by 83 to 13 with 12 stocks stable.
Analysts also said buying should be dampened in the run-up to the September 21 parliamentary eletions.

But they said Tuesday's threat by the co-ruling Peasant Party (PSL) that it would seek to oust the ex-communist premier unless farming policy demands were met represented largely an attempt to boost its popularity before the polls.
Industrial boilermaker Rafako fell 13.8 percent on Wednesday, resuming trade after a suspension since July 11 due to flooding.

The firm, which traded without the daily 10-percent price-fluctuation limit on Wednesday, gave an 18.9-million- zloty ($5.4 million) preliminary flood damage estimate but said this year's sales forecast of 370 million zlotys ($105.6 million) had not been changed.
